unnormalised: Property registrations in Mumbai saw a dip of 7% in July ‘24, according to Knight Frank India. A total of 9,579 units were registered compared to 10,341 units in July ‘23. Experts attribute this slight decrease to the monsoon season and fewer auspicious dates for property buying.
normalised: Property registrations in Mumbai saw a dip of seven percent in July twenty twenty four, according to Knight Frank India. A total of nine thousand five hundred and seventy nine units were registered compared to ten thousand three hundred and forty one units in July twenty twenty three. Experts attribute this slight decrease to the monsoon season and fewer auspicious dates for property buying.

unnormalised: However, despite the monthly dip, the overall outlook remains positive. The report also highlights that apartments priced between ₹50 lakh and ₹1 crore comprised 45% of the total registrations, reflecting sustained demand in the mid-segment housing sector. Areas like Thane West and Navi Mumbai continue to be popular choices, accounting for 30% of new property purchases.
normalised: However, despite the monthly dip, the overall outlook remains positive. The report also highlights that apartments priced between rupee fifty lakh and one crore comprised forty five percent of the total registrations, reflecting sustained demand in the mid-segment housing sector. Areas like Thane West and Navi Mumbai continue to be popular choices, accounting for thirty percent of new property purchases.

unnormalised: An interesting trend observed is the increase in average property size. In July ‘24, the average size of apartments registered was 1050 sq ft, up from 980 sq ft in the same month last year. This indicates a preference for larger homes, driven by work-from-home culture and the desire for more spacious living.
normalised: An interesting trend observed is the increase in average property size. In July twenty twenty four, the average size of apartments registered was one thousand and fifty square feet, up from nine hundred and eighty square feet in the same month last year. This indicates a preference for larger homes, driven by work-from-home culture and the desire for more spacious living.

unnormalised: Looking ahead, analysts predict a strong resurgence in demand during the festive season. With Diwali just around the corner on 31/10/24, developers are gearing up to launch new projects and offer attractive deals. It is expected that property registrations will surpass the 12,000 mark in November, fuelled by positive market sentiment and improved consumer confidence.
normalised: Looking ahead, analysts predict a strong resurgence in demand during the festive season. With Diwali just around the corner on thirty first October twenty twenty four, developers are gearing up to launch new projects and offer attractive deals. It is expected that property registrations will surpass the twelve thousand mark in November, fuelled by positive market sentiment and improved consumer confidence.
